text: Math 317 Quiz 4 Practice Questions Solutions 1. Let S be the sphere x2 + y2 + z2 = a2 for a ﬁxed constant a > 0 oriented outward. Suppose that we parametrize S by using the spherical coordinate: ⃗r (ϕ, θ) = ⟨a sin ϕ cos θ, a sin ϕ sin θ, a cos ϕ⟩, 0 ≤ ϕ ≤ π, 0 ≤ θ ≤ 2π. (a) Show that ∂ϕ⃗r × ∂θ⃗r (ϕ, θ) = a sin ϕ⃗r (ϕ, θ). (b) Using the parametrization, verify that the area of S is 4πa 2. (c) Compute the ﬂux of ⃗F(x, y, z) = ⟨x, y, 0⟩ across S by using the result from (a). (d) Compute the ﬂux of ⃗F(x, y, z) = ⟨x, y, 0⟩ across S by using the divergence theorem. Solution. (a) ∂ϕ⃗r = ⟨a cos ϕ cos θ, a cos ϕ sin θ, −a sin ϕ⟩. ∂θ⃗r = ⟨−a sin ϕ sin θ, a sin ϕ cos θ, 0⟩ ∂ϕ⃗r × ∂θ = ⟨a2 sin 2 ϕ cos θ, a 2 sin2 ϕ sin θ, a 2 sin ϕ cos ϕ⟩ = a sin ϕ⃗r (ϕ, θ). (b) Note that dS = |∂ϕ⃗r × ∂θ|dϕdθ = a sin ϕ|⃗r (ϕ, θ)|dϕdθ = a2 sin ϕdϕdθ. Therefore, the surface area is ∫ ∫ S 1dS = ∫ 2π 0 ∫ π 0 a2 sin ϕdϕdθ = 4πa 2. (c) ⃗F(⃗r (ϕ, θ)) = ⟨a sin ϕ cos θ, a sin ϕ sin θ, 0⟩ ˆndS =a sin ϕ⃗r (ϕ, θ)dϕdθ. ⃗F(⃗r (ϕ, θ)) · ˆndS = a sin ϕ(a2 sin2 ϕ cos 2 θ + a2 sin 2 ϕ sin 2 θ)dϕdθ = a3 sin3 ϕdϕdθ. Therefore, ∫ ∫ S ⃗F · ˆndS = ∫ 2π 0 ∫ π 0 a3 sin3 ϕdϕdθ = 2πa 3 ∫ π 0 sin3 ϕdϕ. It remains to compute the integral above: ∫ π 0 sin 3 ϕdϕ = ∫ π 0 sin ϕ(1 − cos 2 ϕ)dϕ = − cos ϕ + 1 3 cos 3 ϕ        π 0 = 2 − 2 3 = 4 3 . By the computation, we ﬁnd that ∫ ∫ S ⃗F · ˆndS = 2πa 3 4 3 = 8 3 πa 3. Page 1 Math 317 Quiz 4 Practice Questions Solutions (d) Let V be the ball of radius a centered at the origin. By the Divergence theorem, ∫ ∫ S ⃗F · ˆndS = ∫ ∫ ∫ V div ⃗FdV = 2 volume(V ) = 2 · 4 3 πa 3 = 8 3 πa 3. 2. (c) 16.7.11: Using cylindrical coordinate, we parametrize the surface by ⃗r (θ, z) = ⟨2 cos θ, 2 sin θ, z⟩, 0 ≤ θ ≤ π, 0 ≤ z ≤ 1, where the range of θ was determined by the condition y = 2 sin θ ≥ 0. We ﬁrst evaluate the rate of ﬂow in the unit m 3/s (volume per unit time), which is given by the ﬂux of ⃗v across S: ∫ ∫ S ⃗v · ˆndS. Since ⃗r θ × ⃗r z = ⟨−2 sin θ, 2 cos θ, 0⟩ × ⟨0, 0, 1⟩ = ⟨2 cos θ, 2 sin θ, 0⟩ are outward normal vectors, we get ˆndS = ⟨2 cos θ, 2 sin θ, 0⟩dθdz. We can compute the integral using sin3 θ = (1 − cos 2 θ) sin θ, which gives ∫ π 0 sin 3 θdθ = ∫ π 0 sin θ − cos 2 θ sin θdθ = − cos θ + 1 3 cos 3 θ        π 0 = 4 3. Therefore, the rate of ﬂow in the unit m 3/s is ∫ ∫ D⟨z, y2, x 2⟩ · ˆndS = 8 ∫ π 0 sin 3 θdθ = 32 3 . We get the rate of ﬂow in the unit kg/s (mass per unit time) by multiplying the density; 870 kg/m3 × 32 3 m 3/s = 9280 kg/s. (d) 16.7.12: Let S1, S2, · · · , S6 be six sides of the cube with vertices (±1, ±1, ±1). According to Gauss’s Law, the net charge contained in the cube is equal to Q = ϵ0 6∑ j=1 ∫ ∫ Sj ⟨x, y, z⟩ · ˆndS. Suppose that S1 is the face on the plane z = 1, parametrized by ⃗r (x, y) = ⟨x, y, 1⟩, (x, y) ∈ [−1, 1] 2. On S1, we ﬁnd that ˆn = ˆk and dS = |⃗r x × ⃗r y|dxdy = dxdy. Therefore, ∫ ∫ S1⟨x, y, z⟩ · ˆndS = ∫ 1 −1 ∫ 1 −1⟨x, y, 1⟩ · ˆkdxdy = ∫ 1 −1 ∫ 1 −1 1dxdy = 4. By similar computations (or by symmetry), we ﬁnd that the same is true for every Sj; ∫ ∫ Sj ⟨x, y, z⟩ · ˆndS = 4, for 1 ≤ j ≤ 6. Therefore, Q = ϵ0 6∑ j=1 ∫ ∫ Sj ⟨x, y, z⟩ · ˆndS = ϵ06 · 4 = 24ϵ0. Let S be the part of the cylinder x2 + y2 = 4 between the planes z = 0 and z = 5, oriented so that the normal vector at (2, 0, 1) is ⟨1, 0, 0⟩. Compute the ﬂux of the vector ﬁeld ⃗F (x, y, z) = ⟨xy2, y3, 4x2z⟩ across the oriented surface S. Solution. • Direct calculation: we may parametrize S by ⃗r (θ, z) = ⟨2 cos θ, 2 sin θ, z⟩, 0 ≤ θ ≤ 2π, 0 ≤ z ≤ 5, and this gives ⃗r θ × ⃗r z = ±⟨2 cos θ, 2 sin θ, 0⟩dθdz. We need to choose + sign here from the given orientation of S. Therefore, ∫ ∫ S ⃗F · ˆndS = ∫ 2π 0 ∫ 5 0 ⟨8 cos θ sin 2 θ, 8 sin 3 θ, 32 cos 2 θ sin z⟩ · ⟨2 cos θ, 2 sin θ, 0⟩dθdz = ∫ 2π 0 ∫ 5 0 16 sin 2 θ(cos2 θ + sin2 θ)dθdz = 16 · 5 ∫ 2π 0 sin 2 θdθ = 80 ∫ 2π 0 1 − cos 2θ 2 dθ = 80π. • Divergence theorem: Let V be the solid region bounded by x2 + y2 = 4 and z = 0 and z = 5. Then ∂V = S + T + B, where T is the part of the plane z = 5 with x2 + y2 ≤ 4 and B is the part of the plane z = 0 with x2 + y2 ≤ 4. The divergence theorem says that ∫ ∫ S ⃗F · ˆndS + ∫ ∫ T ⃗F · ˆndS + ∫ ∫ B ⃗F · ˆndS = ∫ ∫ ∫ V ∇ · ⃗F dV, so ∫ ∫ S ⃗F · ˆndS = ∫ ∫ ∫ V ∇ · ⃗F dV − ∫ ∫ T ⃗F · ˆndS − ∫ ∫ B ⃗F · ˆndS. (1) On the plane B, ˆn = ⟨0, 0, −1⟩. Therefore, ⃗F · ˆn = −4x2z = 0 since z = 0 on B, which gives ∫ ∫ B ⃗F · ˆndS = 0. (2) Page 5 Math 317 Quiz 4 Practice Questions Solutions On the plane T , ˆndS = ⟨0, 0, 1⟩dxdy. Therefore, ⃗F · ˆndS = 4x2zdxdy = 20x2dxdy since z = 5 on T . This gives ∫ ∫ T ⃗F · ˆndS = ∫ ∫ x2+y2≤4 20x2dxdy = ∫ 2π 0 ∫ 2 0 20r2 cos 2 θ · rdrdθ = 20 ∫ 2 0 r3dr ∫ 2π 0 cos 2 θdθ = 20 · 4 · π = 80π. (3) since ∫ 2π 0 cos 2 θdθ = π using the identity cos2 θ = (cos 2θ + 1)/2. Since ∇ · ⃗F = 4(x2 + y2), using polar coordinates ∫ ∫ ∫ V ∇ · ⃗F dV = ∫ ∫ x2+y2≤4 ∫ 5 0 4(x2 + y2)dzdxdy = 5 ∫ 2π 0 ∫ 2 0 4r2rdrdθ = 160π.
